questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a single kidney presents with a solitary exophytic mass of 4 cm localized at its lower pole. Which amongst the following is the best-recommended management option:(NEET PG 2014)

options.label: D
options.text: Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Partial nephrectomy is the preferred surgical treatment for small, localized renal tumors, particularly in patients with a solitary kidney. This approach helps to preserve renal function while effectively treating the cancer. Radical nephrectomy would result in the patient requiring dialysis or transplantation, which carries a higher risk and greater impact on the patient's quality of life.
  • • Rationale:
  • • Partial nephrectomy: For tumors ≤4 cm, partial nephrectomy is recommended because it offers equivalent cancer-specific survival rates compared to radical nephrectomy while better preserving renal function. Radical nephrectomy: Although this procedure is effective in treating renal cell carcinoma, it is not the best option for patients with a solitary kidney due to the risk of renal failure and the need for dialysis or transplantation. Radical nephrectomy with dialysis: This would significantly impact the patient's quality of life and is not necessary for a small, localized tumor that can be managed with partial nephrectomy. Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation: This option is overly invasive for a small tumor and presents additional risks associated with transplantation.
  • • Partial nephrectomy: For tumors ≤4 cm, partial nephrectomy is recommended because it offers equivalent cancer-specific survival rates compared to radical nephrectomy while better preserving renal function.
  • • Radical nephrectomy: Although this procedure is effective in treating renal cell carcinoma, it is not the best option for patients with a solitary kidney due to the risk of renal failure and the need for dialysis or transplantation.
  • • Radical nephrectomy with dialysis: This would significantly impact the patient's quality of life and is not necessary for a small, localized tumor that can be managed with partial nephrectomy.
  • • Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation: This option is overly invasive for a small tumor and presents additional risks associated with transplantation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Radical nephrectomy : Leads to loss of renal function in a single kidney patient, necessitating dialysis or transplantation.
  • • Option B. Radical nephrectomy
  • • Option C. Radical nephrectomy with dialysis : An avoidable consequence if the tumor can be effectively treated with partial nephrectomy.
  • • Option C. Radical nephrectomy with dialysis
  • • Option D. Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation: Unnecessary for a small, localized tumor and involves higher surgical and postoperative risks.
  • • Option D. Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with a solitary kidney and a small, localized renal tumor (≤4 cm), partial nephrectomy is the preferred management option to preserve renal function and effectively treat the tumor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.

  • ➤ Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment Zone of resonance around the lump

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.correct_answer: C. A second attempt at aspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.
  • • Option A. Incision and Drainage:
  • • Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.
  • • Option B. Continue antibiotics only:
  • • Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.
  • • Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: A fifty-year-old lady presents with a two-year history of recurrent abdominal pain with radiation to her back. The pain is severe in intensity and refractory to simple analgesics. Ultrasound and contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) confirmed the diagnosis and showed a dilated pancreatic duct. Which of the following is the likely recommended surgical procedure of choice: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Longitudinal Pancreatico-Jejunostomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Recurrent abdominal pain radiating to the back in a patient with a dilated pancreatic duct, as confirmed by CECT, suggests a diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis. In cases of chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct, a drainage procedure such as longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (also known as Puestow procedure) is the preferred surgical treatment. This procedure involves creating an anastomosis between the pancreatic duct and the jejunum to allow drainage of pancreatic secretions, thereby relieving pain and preventing further damage to the pancreas.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vagotomy with antrectomy : This procedure is typically used for peptic ulcer disease and is not indicated for chronic pancreatitis.
  • • Option
  • • A. Vagotomy with antrectomy
  • • Option B. Vagotomy with gastrojejunostomy : This combination is also used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and gastric outlet obstruction but not for chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct.
  • • Option
  • • B. Vagotomy with gastrojejunostomy
  • • Option C. Whipple’s procedure: Also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, this is a more extensive surgery used primarily for pancreatic head tumors and other periampullary cancers. It is not the first-line treatment for chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.
  • • Option
  • • C. Whipple’s procedure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is the surgical treatment of choice for chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct, as it provides effective drainage and symptomatic relief.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Delayed or Late Dumping Syndrome, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diarrhea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Late dumping syndrome is a consequence of peptic ulcer surgery characterized by reactive hypoglycemia occurring typically 1-3 hours after meals. It develops when carbohydrate-rich food causes a rapid rise in blood glucose, triggering an excessive insulin response that leads to subsequent hypoglycemia. Diarrhea is typical of early dumping.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2-3 hours after hyperosmolar meal - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping occurs in the second hour after meals, typically 1-3 hours post-meal. The timing is correct.
  • • Option A. 2-3 hours after hyperosmolar meal
  • • Option B. Reactive hypoglycemia - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping is defined as reactive hypoglycemia caused by the carbohydrate load in the small bowel, leading to a rise in plasma glucose, which triggers insulin release and subsequent hypoglycemia.
  • • Option B. Reactive hypoglycemia
  • • Option D. Neuroglucopenic symptoms are prominent - TRUE for late dumping. The symptoms of late dumping include tremor, faintness, prostration, dizziness, and palpitations, which are manifestations of hypoglycemia.
  • • Option D. Neuroglucopenic symptoms are prominent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Late dumping syndrome presents 1-3 hours after meals with hypoglycemic symptoms (tremors, faintness, dizziness) due to reactive hypoglycemia, while diarrhea is characteristic of early dumping syndrome which occurs immediately after meals.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021) Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  • ➤ Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  • ➤ Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Grade V

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.
  • • Option A. Grade I - Incorrect
  • • Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.
  • • Option B. Grade II - Incorrect
  • • Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.
  • • Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age. It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS. Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS. A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting. The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia). Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria. Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.
  • ➤ CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • ➤ It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • ➤ First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • ➤ Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • ➤ A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • ➤ Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • ➤ Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • ➤ The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • ➤ Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • ➤ Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

  • • Option D. Brachial Artery : Upper extremity emboli are significantly less common than lower extremity emboli. The anatomical pathway from common cardiac sources naturally directs most emboli toward the lower limbs rather than the upper limbs.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.
  • • Option A. Jaw Tumor:
  • • Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.
  • • Option B. Dermoid cyst:
  • • Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.
  • • Option D. Sebaceous cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

  • ➤ Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval. CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.
